message.content: This question requires basic knowledge about geology and the formation of natural landscapes. The Grand Canyon was formed by the Colorado River slowly and steadily eroding the rock over millions of years. Option (A) is incorrect because "blazing" implies a fast and intense action, which is not how the canyon was formed. Option (B) is not related to the formation of the Grand Canyon. Option (D) is incorrect because "evaporating" implies the disappearance of the river, which is not how the canyon was formed.

This question requires basic knowledge about the geological formation of the Grand Canyon. Over long periods of time, the Colorado River has been steadily moving and carving through layers of rock, creating the Grand Canyon. Option (A) is incorrect because "blazing" implies a fast and intense movement, which is not the case for the slow process of river erosion. Option (B) is incorrect because "melting" does not apply to the formation of the Grand Canyon. Option (D) is incorrect because "evaporating" refers to the process of liquid turning into gas and is not relevant to canyon formation.

Option (B) is incorrect because "melting" does not pertain to the formation of canyons. Option (D) is incorrect because "evaporating" does not have any relation to the formation of landforms like the Grand Canyon.
